African Parrots

Timneh African Grey

The Timneh African Grey is slightly smaller and darker than the Congo African Grey, with a horn-colored upper beak and a maroon tail. They are known for their intelligence and early talking ability.

Origin
Africa
Size
10-11 inches (25.5-28 cm). Weight: 275-375g (9.7-13.2 oz)
Weight
325g avg.
Noise Level
Moderate. Can be loud, but generally quieter than many other large parrots.

Looking for a Timneh African Grey?

See Available Timneh African Grey Listings

Species Ratings

Talking Ability 9/10
Noise Level 7/10
Social Needs 6/10
Cuddliness 5/10

Temperament & Personality

Intelligent, sensitive, and can be more reserved than the Congo. They are known to be less prone to anxiety.

Vocalization & Talking Ability

Excellent talkers and mimics, often starting at a younger age than Congos. Their voice is less a perfect imitation and more their 'own' voice.

Dietary Needs

A high-quality pelleted diet, supplemented with fresh vegetables, fruits, and some nuts. They require adequate calcium and Vitamin A.

Health & Lifespan

Can live for 50-80 years. Prone to calcium deficiency, Vitamin A and D deficiency, respiratory infections, and feather plucking if bored or stressed.

Housing Requirements

Needs a large space. A minimum cage size of 36"W x 24"D x 48"H is recommended. Not ideal for apartments unless the owner is home a lot and can manage noise.

Common Questions About Timneh African Grey

What is the lifespan of a Timneh African Grey?

The Timneh African Grey typically lives for 50-80 years. With proper care, diet, and regular vet check-ups, they can live a full and healthy life.

Is the Timneh African Grey good for beginners?

This species is rated as 'advanced' care level. They require specific attention, socialization, or dietary needs that may challenge first-time owners.

Where does the Timneh African Grey come from?

The Timneh African Grey is native to Africa.

More African Parrots

Brown-headed Parrot

Quiet. Considered one of the quietest Poicephalus species, they tend to communicate with soft whistles and chirps.

Cape Parrot

Moderate to Loud. They have a powerful call and can be quite vocal, especially during the morning and evening.

Congo African Grey

Moderate to Loud. Can develop loud screams, especially if seeking attention.
